title: How to Use Sumac

steps.headline: Purchase the sumac from a reliable Middle Eastern grocery supplier.
steps.description: Many trees of a related species produce poisonous berries that should not be consumed. Ask for it at Middle East and Armenian grocery stores.

steps.headline: Use sumac in place of lemon or lemon rind in any dish needing a sour, lemony flavor.
Add sumac to dips and dressings.
steps.description: This will enhance the flavor with a sour, lemony taste. Add to vinaigrette before pouring over a salad. Sprinkle sumac over hummus or yogurt dips.

steps.headline: Use as a part of a marinade or condiment for barbecued or grilled meat.
Add it to za'atar.
steps.description: Use this spice blend to sprinkle over vegetables, meat and over flat bread. It can also be added to olive oil as a dip.

steps.headline: Add to a frittata or omelet.
steps.description: Sprinkle liberally with the other ingredients.

steps.headline: Sprinkle over roast vegetables, especially root vegetables.
steps.description: It can also be delicious sprinkled over rice. Sumac is tasty fried with onions on their own.

text: Purchase the sumac from a reliable Middle Eastern grocery supplier. Many trees of a related species produce poisonous berries that should not be consumed. Ask for it at Middle East and Armenian grocery stores. Use sumac in place of lemon or lemon rind in any dish needing a sour, lemony flavor.  Add sumac to dips and dressings. This will enhance the flavor with a sour, lemony taste. Add to vinaigrette before pouring over a salad. Sprinkle sumac over hummus or yogurt dips. Use as a part of a marinade or condiment for barbecued or grilled meat.  Add it to za'atar. Use this spice blend to sprinkle over vegetables, meat and over flat bread. It can also be added to olive oil as a dip. Add to a frittata or omelet. Sprinkle liberally with the other ingredients. Sprinkle over roast vegetables, especially root vegetables. It can also be delicious sprinkled over rice. Sumac is tasty fried with onions on their own.
